RJ, this type of communication is still in the beginning  stages,  these 
f=
ine people are building new equipment, and seem to be coming closer to  wha=
t 
will be needed.  I know it works, most of us do have our own personal  
=
proof, maybe, you take that radio a part and start working with it so, you =
can  
have some of our own proof too. sf
 
 
In a message dated 7/14/2010 7=
:54:43 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time,  
rasterer@... writes:

 
 
 

It =
sounds like you are saying if you are able to  'listen with an open 
mind',=
 then you would be able to determine the  object, I don't know if everyone =

here would agree with you that they  can't listen with an open mind: but 
=
that's between you and  them.

So far, all you've done is describe the ways=
 in which your  technology 
doesn't work. 
I think we'd rather hear some of=
 the ways  in which it does.  


--- On Wed, 7/14/10,  purplespacefriend <p=
urplealiengirl@purpleali>  wrote:

No, I s=
aid it was predictable that the results would be negative.  This 
stuff don=
't work like that. You have to record and listen with an  open mind, 
not a=
 mind that thinks it knows everything. The "proof"  tends to be on a 
perso=
nal level, almost to spite the sketics.  

You know what you can do with yo=
ur  experiments!

F-S

> 
> Thanks again for e=
veryone  who participated! I admire your courage and 
motivation to try  di=
fferent methods, see what works, and try to improve 
everyone's  understand=
ing of EVP-ITC.
> 
> If you recall, on 7/10/2010  I placed an object on top=
 of my computer 
monitor, right in front of  me, and left it there until to=
day, 7/14/2010, noon 
Denver time. The  experiment was for participants to =
determine what it was. 
Vague or  partial answers wouldn't be counted (for =
example, just colors, 
shapes,  sizes, what it's made of, etc): we're looki=
ng for what it is.  
Participants could use their ghost boxes, EVP recorder=
s, or I suppose  any other 
means they chose.
> 
> 
> In order to keep  me =
honest, I took a picture of the object at the start 
of the  experiment and=
 loaded it to the Files section (RJ folder) of this  
group. If you can fol=
low the link, it is here:
> 
> _http://tech._ (http://tech./)  groups.yahoo=
. com/group/ EVP-ITC/files/  
RJ/RJ.20100710. 1.zip
> 
> 
> The idea was th=
at you  could download the file at the beginning of the 
test, and 'keep it=
  safe' on your computer. Then at the end of the test, I 
would release  th=
e password so you could reveal the contents of the file. That 
way,  you we=
re in control of the original image during the entire test, not  
me. 
> 
>=
 
> The password for that file is:  123BlastOff
> Instructions, if you need=
 them, are also in that  RJ folder.
> 
> And if you did not care to downloa=
d the  zip file before the test, I will 
post the final image there  too.
>=
 
> 
> So to the results:
> 
>  Number of participants: 5
> Total tries: 8
=
> Ambiguous  answers: 0
> Correct answers: 0
> 
> Object: A  radio
> Uzippe=
d picture:
> _http://tech._ (http://tech./)   groups.yahoo. com/group/ EVP-=
ITC/files/ 
RJ/RJ.20100710. 1.JPG
>  
> 
> So what do the results mean? All=
 that we can really  agree on from this 
experiment is that no participant,=
 with whatever  theories or methods or 
technology they used, was able to c=
orrectly  determine the object. We can't say 
those theories or methods or =
 technologies never work. Just as we can't say 
they do. Just that, for  wh=
atever reason, they did not work this time. 
Readers can take the  results,=
 use them to improve or change their methods, or 
keep doing  what they're =
doing.
> 
> 
> If anyone has any  observations, comments, or ideas for impr=
ovement, let 
me know. I hope  to get a new experiment up and running soon.=
 Since there 
wasn't much  participation Mon-Wed, I think the next experime=
nt will be 
arranged to  mostly span the weekends.
> 
> 
> Again, thanks to=
  everyone who participated in this first  experiment.
>
